Name: Session1_long
Title: Week 1: Part 2
Description: Welcome! The domains listed here are some areas that may cause teens to feel anxious.Please select the one that you'd like to work on during today's training.

BeforeDomain.Name: Welcome back!
BeforeDomain.Title: Welcome back!
Description: Welcome back to MindTrails! Let’s get started with practicing flexible thinking. Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise.

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 0 = Most calm I could imagine being 10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better.(An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to think about how much you studied, so that you felt less worried?) 0 = Not at all – I wasn’t able to think in different ways to feel better 10 = Completely– I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better I didn’t want/need to change how I was feeling I’m not sure, or I wasn’t paying attention to my feeling

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared?(An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won’t draw attention to yourself?) 0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared 10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway I didn’t have anything that would make me anxious or scared in the last 24 hours

BeforeDomain.Name: Three Brief Questions
BeforeDomain.Title: Three Brief Questions
Description: Thank you!

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: The purpose of this quick exercise is to demonstrate what imagination-based thinking is. You will imagine what seeing, touching, and smelling a lemon is like. Please imagine this as if you are really experiencing it.

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: In this exercise—and throughout the training program—please remember to imagine what is happening through your own eyes, similar to the picture on the left. This is more effective than viewing the situation as an outside observer, like the picture on the right.

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: Okay...let's begin! Imagine you are holding the lemon in your right hand, and you can feel its shape and its weight.

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: Now imagine you are shining a light on the lemon, and you can see the waxy and lumpy texture of the yellow skin.

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: Now imagine that you scratch the skin with your fingernail, then you bring the lemon up to your nose, and you can smell the fresh zesty juice from the skin.

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: Now imagine that you cut the lemon in half, and you bring one half of it up for a closer look. You can see the juicy flesh in the shape of segments that look like a wagon wheel.

BeforeDomain.Name: Lemon Exercsie
BeforeDomain.Title: Lemon Exercise
Description: Now imagine that you squeeze the lemon and some of the juice squirts right into your eyes, and it is really stinging, making your eyes water.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Please describe the situation in a few words:

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real).Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there. Please click the NEXT button and play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task? Press on the bar to see the slider.

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: How vividly did you imagine the situation?

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Items: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly

BeforeDomain.Name: Using Your Imagination
BeforeDomain.Title: Using Your Imagination
Description: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?

Scenarios.Name: Scenario1
Scenarios.Title: Scenario 1
Scenarios.Caption: Answering a question
Description: Your English teacher calls on you to answer a question about the book you just read. You say your best answer and your peers are quiet.
Words: It was nice to be able to share what I think about the book.
My classmates are judging my wrong answer.
My answer sounded dumb because I didn't understand the book, but no one will remember tomorrow.
If my English teacher didn't call on me, I wouldn't have made a fool of myself. I'll have a better answer next time.
I'm glad my teacher gave me the opportunity to share my answer.
I'm satisfied with how I said my answer.
I'm disappointed in myself because I couldn't say what I wanted to say, but I think my teacher understood my point.
I was really anxious while I was answering, but was able to manage my feelings.
I think about my answer, smile, and sit back.
I'll review my notes from this book before my test.
I won't answer again in class.
I feel like I should crack a joke so my friends forget about my answer, but don't.
I want to cry, but I take a moment to calm down and focus on the teacher's next question.
